Reuben Clark Law Society   Latino Law Students Association   Law and Business Association   Law and Film Society   Law and Government Society   Social Enterprise and Startup Law   Law Democrats   Law Revue   Law Rugby   Law Students for Economic Justice   Law Students for Israel   Law Students for Justice in Palestine   NYU Legal Aid Chapter   Sports Law Association   Than the Sword   Law Students for Human Rights   Law Women   Law Students for Reproductive Justice   Learned Foot   Legal Outreach   Media Law Collaborative   Mediation Organization   Mental Health Law Association   Middle Eastern Law Students Association   Muslim Law Students Association   National Lawyers Guild   OUTLaw   Older Wiser Law Students   Open Meditation and Yoga Association (OM)   Prisoners' Rights and Education Project   Public Interest Law Foundation   Public Service Auction   Real Estate and Urban Policy Forum   Recent College Graduate Mentors (RCGM)   Research, Education and Advocacy to Combat Homelessness   South Asian Law Students Association   Student Animal Legal Defense Fund   Student Lawyer Athletic Program   Students for the Education and Representation of Veterans (SERV)   Substantial Performance   Supreme Court Reading Group   Suspension Representation Project   Transfer Student Committee   Trial Advocacy Society   Unemployment Action Center   West Coast Connection   Women of Color Collective               Related Links           Student Bar Association Other Student Organizations                            The Supreme Court Reading Group hosts small, seminar-style events held throughout the year that bring together students and a distinguished guest to talk about a recent or upcoming Supreme Court case. All attendees read key Supreme Court opinions and transcripts prior to the seminar. It’s a great opportunity to kick back, have a drink, and talk SCOTUS with amazing NYU professors, judges, and practitioners.   All events are open only to currently enrolled JD/LLM students; two weeks before an event, we send out a link to an attendee lottery system. If you'd like to join our listserv, simply fill out the form below. If you're having trouble with the list system, have any other questions, or would like to get involved, please feel free to email us .   Listserv Signup   Loading...   SCRG Board   President : Gabriel Panek   VP Operations : S. Riane Harper   VP Communications : Harry Black   Treasurer : Ava Ferenci   Executive Editors : Billy Goldstein and Lin Meneguin   You can contact the Board at supreme-court-reading-group@nyu.edu . Judicial Clerkships | NYU School of Law                          Skip to main content                                     ›               Quicklinks       Areas of Study   Calendar   Career Services   Colloquia   Courses   Departments   Directories   Docket   Housing   Library   News and Press   NYU Home   Student Links   Technology                                              JD Admissions   Faculty & Scholarship   Global Opportunities   LLM/JSD Admissions   Academics & Courses   Law & Business   Executive Education   Current Students   Public Service   About NYU Law   Alumni & Giving   Centers & Institutes                               Home › Career Services › JD Students › Judicial Clerkships                  Career Services                 Judicial Clerkships                 JD Students       First Year JD Career Curriculum   JD Calendar of Events   Your Career Journey   Career Counselors   Judicial Clerkships   Diversity Programs   Recruiting Programs                           New York University School of Law has a very successful judicial clerkship program. Each year more than 130 NYU School of Law graduates work as judicial clerks. Some graduates obtain clerkships during their 3L year and, in keeping with recent hiring preferences of judges, some obtain clerkships after working for a year or more. The last two academic years have been very successful judicial clerkship seasons for NYU Law: more than 320 students and alumni secured clerkships, 98 of which were with federal appellate judges.   During the fall 2014 clerkship term, 166 NYU alumni are clerking: 47 are clerking on the federal Courts of Appeals, including seven on the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and eight on the US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. In addition, six alumni are clerking for state Supreme Court justices and one is clerking on the Delaware Court of Chancery, the nation’s preeminent forum for resolving business disputes. Since 2004, 14 NYU graduates have clerked on the US Supreme Court, and many JD and LLM graduates have clerked on the International Court of Justice in the Hague.   Where NYU Alums Clerk: Locations of Clerkships     Clerkship Application Process   To assist students and alumni with the application process, the Judicial Clerkship Office (JCO) publishes a Judicial Clerkship Handbook which thoroughly details the value of a clerkship, where to clerk, how to apply, when to apply, etc. (see table of contents ). In addition, the JCO publishes an Appendix to the Handbook which lists all past, current, and future NYU clerks of active judges, along with the contact information for the clerks. Most importantly, the JCO offers individualized counseling with our dedicated clerkship career counselor Michelle Cherande ’97.   NYU students and alumni can access the Judicial Clerkship Handbook and Appendices, as well as other valuable resources, by logging on to your Career Services Manager (CSM) account and clicking the “Clerkships” top link. You must complete the registration form before you can access the materials. If you do not have a CSM account, you can register for an account on the student/alum login page.   Judicial Clerkship Office   245 Sullivan Street, Suite 430  New York, NY 10012-1301  Phone: (212) 998-6090  Fax: (212) 995-4076         Full-time Administrators           Michelle Cherande ’97, Director   michelle.cherande@nyu.edu   Jim Nesbitt, Assistant Director   james.nesbitt@nyu.edu                                        In her own words             Adrienne Lee Benson '15 talks about why she wanted a clerkship and how NYU Law helped her reach her goal. Three NYU Law alumni to clerk at Supreme Court in upcoming term | NYU School of Law                           Skip to main content                                     ›               Quicklinks       Areas of Study   Calendar   Career Services   Colloquia   Courses   Departments   Directories   Docket   Housing   Library   News and Press   NYU Home   Student Links   Technology                                              JD Admissions   Faculty & Scholarship   Global Opportunities   LLM/JSD Admissions   Academics & Courses   Law & Business   Executive Education   Current Students   Public Service   About NYU Law   Alumni & Giving   Centers & Institutes                               Home › News › Three NYU Law alumni to clerk at Supreme Court in upcoming term             Three NYU Law alumni to clerk at Supreme Court in upcoming term                 News       Alumni   Centers   Faculty   Global   Students   Press Highlights   For the Media   Faculty Experts                           During the 2012-13 term, three NYU School of Law alumni will hold clerkships at the U.S. Supreme Court. In total, the Court’s nine active justices each have four clerks, while the three retired justices have one apiece. Brian Burgess ’09 will clerk for Justice Sonia Sotomayor. Currently serving as special assistant to the U.S. solicitor general, Burgess previously clerked for Judge David Tatel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and Judge Guido Calabresi of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. At NYU Law, he was a Furman Academic Scholar and received the University Graduation Prize for highest overall academic average after five semesters. He earned an A.B. in philosophy from Dartmouth College.   Ian Samuel ’08 will clerk for Justice Antonin Scalia. He is presently on the appellate staff of the U.S. Department of Justice’s Civil Division, after serving as a Bristow Fellow in the Office of the Solicitor General. Samuel previously clerked for Chief Judge Alex Kozinski of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. He was a Furman Academic Scholar at the Law School. Samuel earned a B.S. in computer science from Truman State University, where he was a national parliamentary debate champion.   Charlotte Taylor ’08 will clerk for Justice Sotomayor. Most recently an academic fellow at Columbia Law School, she previously clerked for Judge Robert Katzmann of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and Judge Jed Rakoff of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. Before attending NYU Law as a Furman Academic Scholar, Taylor was a visiting assistant professor in letters at Wesleyan University. She holds a Ph.D. in English from Yale University and an A.B. in English and French from Duke University.   In the current term, Rebecca Stone ’09 is clerking for Justice Stephen Breyer. She previously clerked for Judge Richard Posner of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. At NYU Law, Stone was a Furman Academic Scholar. Before law school she worked in behavioral economics and was an assistant professor of economics at the University of Leicester. She holds both an M.Phil. and D.Phil. in economics from the University of Oxford as well as a B.A. in politics, philosophy, and economics.
